Um interchange. So what's new with
interchange? I will start with just a
overview of um of what it is and what
you can do with it. Um, basically we the
main goal was to make it more
customizable for people to be able to
tweak the import process, change preset,
add their own step when they import
things in the engine. So very high level
what we do is that you import you want
to import a model or PNG texture or
material in the engine. So the engine so
the intention framework is going to
select the good translation step to read
the file for you. Um then you have
processing step that we call pipelines
here where basically you're going to
take the payload that has been read. Do
you want to apply different settings
like it's a mesh? Do you want do you
want to bake it? Do you want to combine
all the static mesh in one? Do you want
to generate normals? Do you want to
enable nits etc. So this is going there
and this step is going to inform
basically the factories that are
actually going to create your actors and
asset into the into the scene. And so
because it's more modular, it's easier
to now to just come and modify one of
them or create your own steps without
touching the full pipeline. And you can
factories and translator you you would
do that with C++. And for the
um processing step that is usually where
people start to work to adjust their
custom um data prep uh operation. This
this one you can go and do some
